body_html: Basically yes. I have seen C++ examples (even I tried it myself) that can train a graph. To me it seems like gradient calculation functions generally does work on C++ mode. But still based on the description, that gradient ops are only available in python, I'm not sure how they are being ported from python to C++, when we wrap the whole TF core as a shared object library.
body_text: Basically yes. I have seen C++ examples (even I tried it myself) that can train a graph. To me it seems like gradient calculation functions generally does work on C++ mode. But still based on the description, that gradient ops are only available in python, I'm not sure how they are being ported from python to C++, when we wrap the whole TF core as a shared object library.
body: Basically yes. I have seen C++ examples (even I tried it myself) that can train a graph. To me it seems like gradient calculation functions generally does work on C++ mode. But still based on the description, that gradient ops are only available in python, I'm not sure how they are being ported from python to C++, when we wrap the whole TF core as a shared object library.
